div.p: We study the class of operators S α,β obtained by compressing the Hardy shift on the parametric spaces H 2 α,β corresponding to the pair {α, β} satisfying |α| 2 + |β| 2 = 1. We show, for nonzero α, β, each S α,β is indeed a shift M z on some analytic reproducing kernel Hilbert space and present a complete classification of their invariant subspaces. While all such invariant subspaces M are cyclic, we show, unlike other classical shifts, they may not be generated by their corresponding wandering subspaces (M ⊖ S α,β M). We provide a necessary and sufficient condition along this line and show, for a certain class of α, β, there exist S α,β -invariant subspaces M such that M = [M ⊖ S α,β M] S α,β .

div.head: Introduction
div.p: A common theme in the study of invariant subspaces of shift operators on classical function spaces is the relation between wandering subspaces for the operator in question and the associated invariant subspaces. The starting point of this investigation is, of course, the celebrated theorem of A. Beurling ([5]). To begin with, let us recall the definition of a wandering subspace. Throughout this paper, we assume all the Hilbert spaces H are infinitedimensional, separable and over the complex field C. Following Halmos ( [16]), we call a subspace N of a Hilbert space H is wandering for an operator T if N ⊥ T n N for all n ∈ N. Therefore, if a subspace M ⊆ H is T -invariant, then (M ⊖ T M) is always wandering for T . Corresponding to any subset E ⊆ H, [E] T will denote the smallest closed T -invariant subspace generated by {T n f : f ∈ E, n = 0, 1, 2, . . .}, and we say, a T -invariant subspace M satisfies wandering subspace property (w.s.p. for short) if M = [M ⊖ T M] T . Again, if a wandering subspace N satisfies [N ] T = H, we call N a generating wandering subspace for T . Note that, if N is a generating wandering subspace and N = Cf for some f ( = 0) ∈ H, H is cyclic. With this terminology, let us now state Beurling's Theorem: Theorem 1.1. Let M = {0} be a closed subspace of H 2 (D) invariant under the unilateral shift S. Then dim(M ⊖ SM) = 1 and there exists an inner function θ such that
div.formula: M = [θ] S = [M ⊖ SM] S .
div.p: Hence, the map M −→ M ⊖ SM sets a one-one correspondence between the invariant and wandering subspaces of S on H 2 (D). Also, all nonzero wandering subspaces are one-dimensional and generated by an inner function. Beurling's Theorem plays a crucial role in Operator and Complex Function Theory. It is only natural to look for analogues of the above result in other function spaces. We mention two pertinent examples. First is the Dirichlet space. In ( [18]), it is shown that, the shift invariant subspaces on Dirichlet space D, satisfy the similar properties like Hardy-shift i.e., M z -invariant subspaces on D are generated by their corresponding wandering subspaces and the nonzero wandering subspaces are of dimension one. Second is the Bergmann space. Unlike the case of Hardy and Dirichlet spaces, the shift M z on Bergmann space L 2 a (D) ( [4]) exhibits different behaviour. The wandering subspaces of M z on L 2 a (D) can be of any dimension. In fact, it is shown in ( [1]): For every n ∈ N {∞}, there exists an invariant subspace M ⊆ L 2 a (D) such that dim(M ⊖ zM) = n. Also, if an M z -invariant subspace M in L 2 a (D) is cyclic, then dim(M⊖zM) = 1. Hence, not every Bergmann shift invariant subspaces are cyclic. However, despite this contrast with Hardy and Dirichlet shifts, any M z -invariant subspace on L 2 a (D) is still generated by the corresponding wandering subspace. This result is proved in ( [6]) and formally states as:
div.formula: Theorem 1.2. Let M ⊆ L 2 a (D) be M z -invariant. Then M = [M ⊖ zM] Mz .
div.p: Therefore, in all these three cases of classical shift operators on Hardy, Dirichlet and Bergmann spaces, we note that: A shift-invariant subspace M can be recovered from its wandering subspace M ⊖ zM . At this point, one may ask: What if we perturb the classical shifts a bit? If the resulting operator ( obtained by perturbing a classical shift) is a shift on some function Hilbert space, what can be said about their invariant and wandering subspaces? How (if at all) are these two subspaces related?

Here shift refers to an operator unitarily equivalent to the multiplication operator M z on some analytic reproducing kernel Hilbert space. For the detailed theory on reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces, we refer ( [4]). Throughout, S will denote the usual unilateral shift on H 2 (D). Our aim in this paper is to seek analogues of the above results for the compressions of the unilateral shift S on the closed subspaces H 2 α,β of the Hardy space. We observe that, these compressions are indeed shifts and can also be represented as perturbations of the Hardy shift. This allows us to study the shifts S α,β in the light of perturbation theory and motivates the questions that we answer here. The analysis of perturbations of the form M z + F where M z is a shift and F is some finite rank (or compact, Hilbert-Schmidt, etc.) operator has been studied extensively in the literature (e.g. [2], [14], [15], [17]). The structure of their invariant subspaces and many essential properties like Normality, Hyponormality, etc. have received enormous attention ( [7], [8], [9], [12]). While Substantial amount of work has been done on characterization of invariant subspaces of perturbations, many of them ( [2], [17], [20]) evidently show, even dealing with rank one perturbations of shifts can be challenging. To study the invariant subspaces of a perturbation of form S + F corresponding to the Hardy shift S, it is natural to look into the techniques and theories built for S. It is also natural to look for the connection between the corresponding structure and properties of S + F and S. In our study, we establish a relation between the S α,β -invariant and Hardy shift-invariant subspaces. In fact, we show in section 3: For every nonzero, closed S α,β -invariant subspace M, there exists an inner function θ (unique upto a scalar multiple) such that either M = z 2 θH 2 (D) or dim(M ⊖ z 2 θH 2 (D)) = 1 (see Theorem 3.3). (see Theorem 4.1). Based on that, we provide a complete characterization of closed S α,β -invariant subspaces M of H 2 α,β (Theorem 4.3). Also, Theorem 4.1 provides a representation of a generating function of the one-dimensional subspace (M ⊖ S α,β M), which plays a crucial role in dealing with wandering subspace property (w.s.p.) in the next section.

• In Section 5, we discuss on the wandering subspaces of S α,β . We show, in contrast with the Hardy shift, ker S * α,β need not generate the full space H In the later part of the same section, we consider the w.s.p. of the non-trivial closed S α,βinvariant subspaces M. We provide a necessary and sufficient condition for M = [M ⊖ S α,β M] S α,β to hold (see Theorem 5.4) and clarify it with concrete examples. Eventually, this directs us to investigate the w.s.p. of S α,β -invariant subspaces with |β| 2 < 1 4+γ , where γ is the unique real root of the cubic polynomial z 3 + 7z 2 + 12z − 1.
